items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
Per the collective bargaining agreement between the Faculty Association AFT 157 and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District Article 9.20 submission and recommendation: Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned service during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of the full load.
		 
Article 9.20 ASSIGNMENT LENGTH AND MAXIMUM LOADING - Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all Districts assigned service during the college semester for which the y are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of a full load.   
Therefore, the attached information is in compliance with Article 9.20 of the Faculty Association AFT 6157 Collective Bargaining Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees.  District Policy adopted on April 10, 2007 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval.  All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the bid limit (current bid limit is $81,000) should have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts that, although are not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts and purchase orders for the period of August 10, 2012 through September 9, 2012 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details: The Board of Trustees adopted the District's operating budget at its meeting on September 11, 2012.  As required by Board Policy 6250, subsequent budget transfers and revisions must be approved by the Board of Trustees.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the resolution authorizing the budget transfers and revisions of funds within expenditure accounts, and authorizing the appropriation of the receipt of unanticipated revenues in certain programs.

items.item_details:
The District historically enters into approximately 50 preventative maintenance agreements for copiers annually with eight different vendors to service its aging fleet of copiers, many of which are beyond their useful life.  In order for the District to enjoy economies of scale, replace its aging fleet of copiers, ease the administration of contracts associated with copier needs, reduce energy consumption, expand functionality and capabilities for departments (e.g., all-in-one copy, fax, scan, etc.), and to maximize the use of general obligation dollars, the District issued an RFP to 13 potential vendors on May 25, 2012.
	 
Two vendors responded to the RFP and the responses were evaluated by an evaluation committee comprised of a purchasing agent, the Assistant Director of Fiscal Services, an ITSS manager, a staff accountant, the CTSS Supervisor, and the Vice President of Administrative Services from both campuses.  Both vendors were invited to meet with the evaluation committee to discuss their proposal.  The evaluation committee is recommending that the Board award a contract to Konica Minolta Business Solutions for $217,440 annually for twelve million black and white copies and 312,000 color copies, which is the District's current annual usage, or $.0163 per black and white copy and $.07 per color copy, whichever is greater.
	 
Approximately 35% of the contract is for hardware, which can be expensed to Measure G - 2010 for capital equipment.
	 
The RFP and the response from Konica Minolta Business Solutions is attached for reference.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees award a contract for a period of five years to Konica Minolta Business Solutions for $217,440 or $.0163 per black and white copy and $.07 per color copy annually, whichever is greater.

items.item_details:
Board Policy 7080.203 defines Class III records as including, but not limited to, detailed records relating to:   records basic to an audit, including those relating to attendance, average daily attendance, or a business or financial transaction (purchase orders, invoices, warrants, ledger sheets, canceled checks and stubs, student body and cafeteria fund records, etc.), and detailed records used in the preparation of any other report.
	 
Board Policy 7080.204 states that Class III records basic to an audit shall not be destroyed until after the third July 1st succeeding the completion of the audit required by Education Code 84040 or of any other legally required audit, or after the ending date of any retention period by an agency other than the State of California, whichever date is later.
	 
Fiscal Services has the following Class III records that meet the three-year criteria for destruction:
	 
Paid Invoices from Fiscal Year 2006-2007
Cash Receipts from Fiscal Year 2006-2007
Financial Aid Records from Fiscal Year 2006-2007
Budget Transfers from Fiscal Year 2006-2007
Petty Cash Reimbursements from Fiscal Year 2006-2007
Check Registers from Fiscal Year 2006-2007
Employee Reimbursements from Fiscal Year 2006-2007
Cash/Bank Reconciliations from Fiscal Year 2006-2007
Journal Vouchers from Fiscal Year 2006-2007
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the destruction of records as listed per Section 7080.302 of the Retention and Destruction of Records under Board Policies.

items.item_details:
The State Chancellor's Office has awarded the San Jose Evergreen Community College District $172,500 to support the Economic and Workforce Development Program (EWD).
	 
The grant supports the salary and benefits of the Director of Economic Development and associated program expenses to meet the following objectives for FY 2012-13:
	 
1.  Provide technical assistance to support the work of the Centers of Excellence (COE), EWD Initiative sector navigators, regional colleges, and the State Chancellor's Office.
	 
2.  Conduct marketing and visibility activities for the COE Initiative and the statewide Economic and Workforce Development Program.
	 
3.  Identify emerging technologies and new research approaches and incorporate them into COE's work.
	 
4.  Increase the strategic presence of the Centers of Excellence with key internal and external partners.
	 
5.   Promote program sustainability for the Centers of Excellence Initiative.
	 
6.  Track the outcomes and maintain reporting and accountability for the initiative and the Statewide Leadership project.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees accept and appropriate the Economic and Workforce Development Grant in the amount of $172,500 for the period of July 1, 2012 to June 30, 2013.

items.item_details: The Political Reform Act requires every local governmental agency (such as school districts) review its Conflict of Interest Code every even-numbered year. Government Code section 87303 states that, "No conflict of interest code shall be effective until it has been approved by the code-reviewing body." The code-reviewing body for the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District is the County of Santa Clara Board of Supervisors. A draft Conflict of Interest Code for SJECCD was submitted to the Santa Clara Board of Supervisors for review, and the draft was returned with some recommended changes by the County Counsel on September 19, 2019. (These changes are indicated in the attached redlined copy. The changes related to the addition and deletion of positions were added by the district, also highlighted in red.) Because the County of Santa Clara Board of Supervisors requires that the governing board of the district approve the code before the final version is submitted by the October 31, 2012, deadline, the district recommends the Board of Trustees approve the attached Conflict of Interest Code.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the District's 2012 Conflict of Interest Code.

items.item_details:
The District Technology Plan process was initiated in earnest in July 2012 to strengthen the District planning effort with a focus on technology.  While it was a very ambitious timeline, the effort to develop this plan was extensive and involved many stakeholders.  This plan is a living document and considered a starting point for District technology planning efforts. This is a high level strategic plan and is not meant to dictate specific IT solutions but rather to identify areas of focus.  Moreover, this plan is meant to align with the Colleges' technology plans and be complementary to those efforts. There is still a significant amount of work to be done to prioritize and operationalize IT planning.           
	 
Highlights of Effort:
12 member Core Authoring Team – goal was to produce this document as a starting point for technology planning
3 month process – included contributions from 21 Committees and Public meetings at time of printing – effort is continuing
Process designed to meet accreditation requirements (alignment of District and College Plans)
Goal was to be inclusive of all stakeholders
40 initiatives identified encompassing all aspects of technology (ERP, Mobile, DE, Fid, VC, BYOD)
Next steps:
Prioritize initiatives
Identify resources for initiatives
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the District Technology Plan as submitted.

items.item_details:
ACCEPT AS INFORMATION ITEMS 
Project Highlights 
Program Update
Presentation by Gilbane Building Company to update the Board on topics related to management of the Measure G-2010 Bond Program.
	 
SJCC – Project Updates 
Presentation by Gilbane Building Company to update the Board on projects and activities at the SJCC campus related to the Measure G-2010 Bond Program.
	 
Monthly Measure G-2010 Summary Report through September 30, 2012 
Attached please find the Measure G-2010 Summary Report through September 30, 2012.
	 
APPROVE AS ACTION ITEMS 
Contracts
Division of the State Architect (DSA) fees for the EVC South Campus Development Project, #32107 
	 
DSA plan review and construction oversight for new construction and alterations is governed by the provisions of the Field Act contained in the California Education Code, Sections 81130, et. seq. for community colleges.  The Field Act imposes important requirements on California schools that are not present in other types of construction approval processes.
	 
The South Campus Development project at Evergreen Valley College falls under this jurisdiction and will participate in DSA’s Collaborative Process, typically resulting in reduced plan review durations.  The DSA fee is paid in the early stages of the design phase for projects entered in the Collaborative Process.  For this project, the DSA fee is $199,520.  (The final fee value will be adjusted based on the actual construction cost of the project after all of the work is complete.)
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of a fee payment to DSA in the amount of $199,520 for the South Campus Development at EVC.
	 
Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) – HMC Architects - Professional Services for District Design Standards
	 
It is typical for a District to develop design standards for various and certain products, finished and room usage.  SJECCD does not have a consolidated design standards book.  An effort in early 2011 was made to identify the current materials and uses that exist but that information needs to be thoroughly developed to identify the requirements for all future project designs.
	 
Based on a proposal and interview competition, HMC Architects (HMC) was selected and approved by the Board to provide programming design services for the South Campus Development at EVC.  Based on their exceptional performance, HMC’s contract was subsequently extended to provide full design services for the project when the construction delivery method was changed to Lease/Lease-back.  Considering the impact that this significant project will have on selection of appropriate, sustainable building products and materials for future projects, and the fact that it is the most advanced project in design, it is recommended that HMC expand their specification effort to include the refinement of the District’s Draft Design Standards.  The final version of the Design Standards will be used for all future projects District-wide and will be germane to each campus as applicable.  HMC has established and produced similar and impressive Design Standards for several Community College Districts.  Their proposal for this work was reviewed and subsequently negotiated for scope and cost as reflected by the Independent Contractor Agreement. 
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of an ICA for professional services to support finalization of District Design Standards to HMC Architects in the amount of $245,000.
	 
Contract – Radiant Electric, Inc. – Evergreen Valley College 21kV Electrical Upgrade Project
	 
The primary electrical service at Evergreen Valley College is a combination of original components from 1974 and a few recent upgrades.  On June 11, 2012 EVC suffered a serious six-day failure to that system which knocked power out to the entire campus and adjacent neighborhoods. During the investigation and effort to repair the failure, serious issues of age and lack of maintenance were identified throughout the system.  An engineering firm was contracted to assess the system.  Based on its report a project was developed to replace the entire primary system cabling and address the numerous maintenance issues found.
	 
Using this documentation District Purchasing issued a Request for Bids, requesting proposals for the Evergreen Valley College 21kV Electrical Upgrade Project. Bids were opened on September 27, 2012 and based on the evaluation of the bid prices and required documentation, Radiant Electric, Inc. was the lowest apparent and responsible bidder to provide the electrical contracting services.
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of a contract to Radiant Electric, Inc. in the amount of $ 1,585,000 for the Evergreen Valley College 21kV Electrical Upgrade Project.
	 
	 
Contract Revisions and Changes 
None
	 
	 
Bond List Revisions 
None
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees accept the Information Items and approve the Action Items, which include Contracts, and Contract Revisions and Changes.

items.item_details:
Proposition 39, which governs the District’s general obligation bonds, requires the establishment of a citizens’ oversight committee.  Following the passage of Measure G-2004 on November 2, 2004, the Board of Trustees took action on May 10, 2005 to establish a Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee.    Measure G-2010 was passed by the voters on November 2, 2010, after which the Board of Trustees took action on December 14, 2010 to amend and restate the bylaws to allow for the existing committee to support both Measure G-2004 and Measure G-2010.
	 
The Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee (CBOC) is required by statute to meet at least annually to review the District’s Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 bond projects plan and to ensure that bond funds are being appropriately used as authorized by the voters.  There are no penalties defined in law for failure to convene a citizens’ oversight committee; however, the spirit of the law contemplates that districts will make every reasonable effort to ensure that the committee functions at least once each year to fulfill its statutory duties.  The current CBOC convenes quarterly for meetings.
	 
Pursuant to Proposition 39, the Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee is required to have a minimum of one (1) student active in a community college support group, such as student government, on the Committee.  This required seat is currently vacant. Mr. Michael Casas submitted his application as a student representative on the Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee to Vice Chancellor Smith.  It is requested that Mr. Casas be appointed to the Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee by the Board of Trustees.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the appointment of Mr. Michael Casas as a Student Representative for the Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee for a term of two years commencing October 9, 2012.
items.item_text: Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee Appointment

items.item_details:
At the September 11, 2012 Board of Trustees’ Meeting, the initial draft of the Milpitas Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to Develop a Joint-Use 21st Century Education Center was presented. The MUSD Board of Trustees also received the initial draft at its September Board meeting.  
	 
Based upon the input received from the initial reading and legal counsels’ further review, minor revisions were made to the document.  The edits are as follows:
	 
The date of the document was updated to reflect October 9, 2012.
	 
The reference name of the center in the initial paragraph was corrected to match the title of the document (Joint-Use 21st Century Education Center), and the short form reference to the Center was consistently edited throughout the document to be “Joint Use Center”.
	 
5.1 was updated to include the approximate enrollment of MUSD.
	 
7.1 was edited to allow site selection to occur and speak to land value.
	 
The language in 7.2 – 7.3 was further worked through by the attorneys for clarity purposes and the paragraphs re-ordered.
	 
A new paragraph was added to Section 8, creating a new 8.1, to further clarify intent, and minor language adjustments were made in the remaining paragraphs.
	 
Paragraph 16 was slightly adjusted to handle the details of the types of insurance coverage the facility may require in the Final Agreement.
	 
A Joint Board Meeting and signing of the MOU is scheduled for November 13, 2012.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to Develop a Joint-Use 21st Century Education Center with Milpitas Unified School District.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Congress by Public Law 100-402, President Barack Obama issued a Presidential Proclamation proclaiming September 15 through October 15, 2012, as National Hispanic Heritage Month.
	 
It is hereby recommended that the Board of Trustees of the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District approve a resolution in support of National Hispanic Heritage Month 2012, and the many students, faculty, staff and administrators of Latino and Hispanic heritage that have made numerous contribution of great value to our colleges. The district also expresses appreciation to the many faculty and staff members, who have created educational events in September and October that paid tribute to National Hispanic Heritage Month 2012.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 100912-2 in support of National Hispanic Heritage Month.
items.item_text: Resolution in Support of National Hispanic Heritage Month

items.item_details: Supporting families and workers in their ability to earn a living wage is entirely consonant with the mission, vision and values of the San Jose Evergreen Community College District. The Board of Trustees has been keenly aware of the high cost of living in our service area and the plight of the “working poor” who do not earn enough to support the needs of their families.  It is for this reason that the Board is in support Measure D included in the November 6, 2012, Ballot that would raise the minimum wage in San Jose from $8 to $10 an hour.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 100912-3 in support of Measure D - Increase in Minimum Wage.
